text: But getting through a hard day makes the next hard day a little easier. It’s muscle memory more than strength, but it works.

I still love you. Xo.
author: anamariecox

text:
You deserve help. I promise with all my heart and life that this is true. I know it’s true because I eventually came to believe I deserved it, and believing in our mutual worthiness is what can save us all. 

Be well. Take care of yourself. I love you.
author: anamariecox

text: I am going to put the phone down and enjoy the last day of vacation but one Big Thought on this before I go: people often congratulate me on my bravery or strength on this day. But recovery isn’t about either of those things, it’s about accepting help.
author: anamariecox

text:
By the grace of God & the fellowship of others in recovery, today I celebrate eight years clean & sober. 

If you struggle with a substance or mental illness (or both, like me) & think there’s no hope for you, know I have been where you are. And now I’m here, and I love company.

text: A difference in what FBI and BJS tally: FBI can’t include crimes that have a “hate” aspect (shouted slurs, for ex) but aren’t reported as a “hate crime.” Only 7% of the BJS crimes are later “confirmed” by police as hate crimes. https://www.bjs.gov/content/pub/pdf/hcv0415_sum.pdf …
author: anamariecox

text: Hate crimes are also an epidemic. FBI says hate crimes *reported as hate crimes*  17% to around 7k, US Bur of Justice Stats—who base their numbers on community surveys—says real number is closer to *250,000*, ANNUALLY, 54% are completely unreported. https://www.bjs.gov/index.cfm?ty=pbdetail&iid=5967 …

text: And, fwiw, I used to mock trigger warnings and safe spaces as the bullshit demands of an already overly-coddled demographic, and then I realized that there was some stuff that *triggered me.* TWs and safe spaces aren’t about coddling, they’re about respect.

text: Current events demand a new pinned tweet.
author: anamariecox

text:
The Blasey-Ford hearings showed media orgs and pundits have gotten *much better* about trigger warnings and offering the @RAINN hotline to those for whom the subject of sexual assault might cause distress.

Let’s not let the chaos of the Virginia situation change that.
author: anamariecox

text:
If you are a survivor of sexual assault, please know:

- you didn’t deserve it
- you didn’t cause it
- you don’t have to talk about it
- you are believed
- you are loved

If you *do* want outside support, you can contact @RAINN at 800-656-4673. 

I believe you. I love you.
author: anamariecox

text: Our relationship reminds me that there are very few of us that are beyond the reach of acceptance and even redemption. It may take a miracle to change their minds but luckily I believe in those, too. /7
author: anamariecox

text: And probably the most controversial point I’ll make: I continue down this road in part because I do get something out of having my in-laws in my life, I mean, beyond more Christmas presents and family harmony. They’re generous people who love me despite *my* outspoken views. /6
author: anamariecox

text: For me, “what I can live with” can probably be short handed to “not hiding my own views but also not picking fights.” I am privileged that *who I am* isn’t a problem for my FiL. (I’m cis, white, able-bodied, etc.) My hope is to use that privilege rather than hide behind it. /5
author: anamariecox

text: And I want to not be on auto-pilot about our differences. He may someday say something that crosses a line; I may have to tag out of visits. But I also want to be there for my nieces & nephew, to be one of the few people in their lives who doesn’t think like their grandpa. /4
author: anamariecox

text: I consider it something of a success that he knows that someone in his life who he loves and respects finds what he has to say not just wrong but *offensive.* But I also know I’ll never change his mind. /3
author: anamariecox

text: Everyone’s calculus is different, but the general math ends in figuring out what you can live with, just for today. My in-laws are Trump supporters; my FiL likes to get under my skin. Sometimes I argue with him. Sometimes I leave the room. /2
author: anamariecox

text: If there’s one thing doing @crooked_friends has taught me, it’s that there’s no one right answer for how to deal with people you love who hold views that don’t align with yours. Arguing and shunning have their place! (And aren’t incompatible with continuing to love someone.) /1

text: I have been arguing that the WH beat is a waste of talent *for years,* but then it was just kind of sad, now I think it’s actively *bad for democracy.* CNN suing the WH plays into Trump’s tiny hands: When someone is throwing a tantrum, the solution isn’t more attention.

text: 3) I am always on the hunt for good substitutes for using wine/beer in stews and today I tried 100% *tart cherry juice* with a splash of balsamic — might be the closest match yet, but different in a tasty way: it’s a deeper flavor than you’d think juice could give.
author: anamariecox

text:
1) So searing the meat in small batches, so you can make sure each side gets a bit of char on it: you’re going to get a LOT of fond.

2) Rinse/deglaze with some water if it starts to smoke. Pour that deliciousness over the meat you’ve already seared and reserved in a bowl.
author: anamariecox

text:
I was not born yesterday!

Though this is the first time I’ve taken the time to do the meat in batches, to each piece seared on every side. And I’d deglaze when the fond got looking burned — whisk around a bit of water, then pour THAT goodness over the already-seared pieces.
author: anamariecox

text: I was so upset today that I went beyond procrasti-baking and instead made beef stew from scratch. If you are ever wondering whether *really* searing the meat and building up a good, thick fond is worth it…. it is worth it.

text:
If you need to stay in bed today (and you can)—stay. Unplug if you want to (and can). Remember to eat, to drink water, to call a friend. Look at cute animal pix. Light a candle. Take a bath. 

Take today off. The fight isn’t going anywhere, and we need you to be strong tomorrow.

text: ALSO: It doesn’t matter if *you* were sober or not. Apologies for not saying that right away. Again, RAINN can help, and call 800-656-HOPE for the National Sexual Assault Hotline.
author: anamariecox

text: BUT if you’re the person that’s been harmed by someone drunk or high, *your* recovery doesn’t depend on that person recovering. And if you’ve experienced sexual violence, whether that person was drunk doesn’t matter at all. And you are not alone @RAINN 800-656-HOPE /fin
author: anamariecox

text: I also mention it bc my fear of *having to face* what I did drunk *kept me drunk* for a long time. If that’s you, I have an assurance and an incredible promise: 1) Wallowing in guilt isn’t part of recovery and 2) At some point, if you stay sober, you’ll WANT to face your past. /5
author: anamariecox

text: Granted, *as far as I know* I never did anything like what Kavanaugh is accused of. And *he* hasn’t claimed being drunk as an excuse but since the idea is out there, my $.02. /4
author: anamariecox

text: Sometimes, that person will still want a full apology. OK, I can apologize for even putting that person in a situation where I was ABLE to do something hurtful. But I’ve also had the experience of someone not realizing I was in a blackout, and that taking a lot of sting out. /3
author: anamariecox

text: I have had someone confront me with something that I had *no memory* of doing. Here’s what I said: “I don’t remember doing that, but I am in no position to deny it. What can I do to make this right? What do you need from me?” /2
author: anamariecox

text: Since black-out drinking has come up… I have some experience. I did things I’d never do sober, that I haven’t done since. Please don’t judge me on based on that. Judge me on how I handle the aftermath. Being drunk isn’t an excuse, just an explanation, and I am still responsible.
author: anamariecox

text: The way I understood it from the trainer, this was less about “dominance” than exuding calm.
author: anamariecox

text: Yup, this is another tool in our belt. Giving him a command also takes uncertainty out of the situation — he knows his role, and my role, and that should make him less insecure about the approaching trigger.
author: anamariecox

text: oh, sorry, Ex is reactive to dogs, too. I should have mentioned that! BUT ONLY AROUND OUR BUILDING… he’s very popular at day care!
author: anamariecox

text: I feel like there is a powerful lesson here about the power of faith and love, but also hot dogs. FIN
author: anamariecox

text: All that confidence in our own abilities is (magically?) supposed to transfer to Ex, too. He will calm down as he trusts us to handle him, handle his world, not give him anything he can’t handle. /10
author: anamariecox

text: And then, the hardest part: If he does react or flip out or go nuclear…have confidence in our ourselves to dial him back down. If WE don’t think we can handle him, he’ll sense it and that (as you can imagine) would further freak him out (“Mom and dad are also scared?????”) /9
author: anamariecox

text: As for 2) confidence. This is as much about us as it is him. First, we have to be confident enough in our handling skills to be able to take him through some simple exercises/tricks BEFORE we walk. He can’t leave for a walk amped up, or unsure of “who’s in charge.” /8
author: anamariecox

text: The same basic idea for his being reactive on walks: carry yummy treats always, and when we sense him starting to react (his ears flip forward, he stiffens up), or if we see a potential trigger: “hot dogs rain from the sky.” /7
author: anamariecox

text: The hot dog trick seems almost too simple to work. It’s a straightforward bribe, right? But the idea is that he starts to associate new people/people in his territory with, as the trainer put it, “hot dogs raining from the sky.”  /6
author: anamariecox

text: 1) We are to feed him hot dogs (or cheese, something “high value”) while we start inviting agreeable friends over. People willing come over and wait in the entry way while he noms the hot dog, and then slowly come in, and then maybe feed Ex hot dogs themselves. /5
author: anamariecox

text: We told her his breed profile (Aussie, border collie, terrier) and her response? “Well, he’s actually pretty calm for an adolescent dog with that background.” And then she told us the secret to helping him overcome his nervousness: hot dogs and self-confidence. /4
author: anamariecox

text: Oh god I just realized I should say right now WE LOVE HIM AND ARE KEEPING HIM FOREVER, I THINK HE IS PERFECT. This is not a Lena Dunham situation. I hope no one was holding their breath. Just getting to the part where we had a TRAINER COME OVER. /3
author: anamariecox

text: “Flipping out” is a little dramatic. Mostly, it’s just barking, agitation. But a few times he’s pulled me off my feet and one time he nipped a guy’s pant leg. We stopped having people over a couple of months ago. Have timed our entries/exits from the building with great care.  /2
author: anamariecox

text: Exley superfans on this website may know that we have been a little worried about Ex. He is “highly reactive,” as they say. He’s doll around the house, and at day care, and dog park, but flips out if he sees anyone in or around our condo building. Also he hates children. /1

text: A deadline calls but I’d like to add to this thread. If anyone has suggestions for mental health resources for under-served communities, send ‘em, please.
author: anamariecox

text: The DACA Mental Health Project provides free mental health services for DACA recipients and their families in and around LA.
author: anamariecox

text: If you are person of color, the @CrisisTextLine also runs The Steve Fund (text STEVE to 741741). A round of resources for Black people here (https://www.ebony.com/life/black-mental-health-resources …).
author: anamariecox

text: For some of us (hi, anyone who is not straight/white/cis/able-bodied), help can be harder to find…but you have some specific resources. If you are LGTBQ: @TrevorProject (for young folk) Trans Lifeline (877-565-8860) GLBT National Help Center (1-888-843-4564)
author: anamariecox

text: My theme here is help. I cannot emphasize this enough: I suffered for years (maybe decades) bc I wasn’t honest about the help I needed. I thought I didn’t deserve it or was weak for wanting it or it wouldn’t come. I was wrong on all counts—and if you think this way, you are too.
author: anamariecox

text:
And here’s the piece I wrote about letting ourselves be vulnerable in public — so that we can be open to help. https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/posteverything/wp/2018/06/09/celebrities-arent-the-only-ones-who-struggle-to-appear-perfect-or-who-need-help/?utm_term=.2fbf29c5ea2e …

/4
author: anamariecox

text:
After Kate Spade and Anthony Bourdain died, I started this thread about the ways that the kindness of strangers can help bridge the gap between suffering and maybe getting help. Totally uplifting (but still get professional help if you need it). https://twitter.com/anamariecox/status/1005080597038059520?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw%7Ctwcamp%5Etweetembed%7Ctwterm%5E1005080597038059520&ref_url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.indy100.com%2Farticle%2Fdepression-mental-health-ana-marie-cox-samaritans-suicide-twitter-8390876 …

/3
author: anamariecox

text: If you are suffering, if you think you MIGHT need help, then you deserve help. My own story taught me that considering suicide — even in a casual way, not “seriously” — is an early warning sign, not “just a cry for help.” Need some guidance? Try @800273TALK or @CrisisTextLine  /2
author: anamariecox

text:

text: The alternative to amplification isn’t censorship, it’s telling a more complete story. You can include Bannon’s views, sure — but see them through the lens of those harmed.
author: anamariecox

text: Droopy socks to own the libs.
author: anamariecox

text: Elevating voices such as Bannon’s isn’t a neutral action. Including them in a “festival of ideas” legitimizes them. “Debate” doesn’t diminish the power of hate. My fellow journalists, please, please read “The Oxygen of Amplification” before you drop your take.
author: anamariecox

text: Will continue to RT this for as long as dumb “silencing”/“censorship” complaints turn up in my TL. Before you pout about the impact of Bannon’s disinvitation, read/listen to @wphillips49 on the impact of INCLUDING voices like his in the national conversation.
author: anamariecox

text: Whitney’s reports offers thoughts on those alternatives! One idea is there is a fourth option beyond debate/silence/shout when it comes to white nationalists: elevate the voices of those *targeted* by their ideas. You will learn a lot about white nationalism that way. I promise.
author: anamariecox

text: And then watch how people (and publications) handle being called out for acting in bad faith — publishing quotes out of context, cherry-picking data, whatever — if not admit fault, do they engage, at least? I try to. I think it’s the best we can do in a fallen world.
author: anamariecox

text: This is a fantastic question. I don’t think there is one publication that that always, totally never operates in bad faith. I don’t think any one person could do that, either. And the left is not innocent. *I* am not innocent. I think the best you can do is to read widely—
author: anamariecox

text:
And when you start thinking on your own about what else you can do, when you start living your amends rather than thinking of your amends as a means to get back what you had before…

/4
author: anamariecox

text:
It might mean hearing other survivors’ stories. It might mean service work. It might mean donating money. 

Whatever it is, you do it. 

And then you ask “What else can I do?” And you do it.  /3
author: anamariecox

text: You may not like what you hear! It might be more than just counseling! “Making things right” might include not being present in the victims’ lives (staying out the public eye), it might mean volunteering to share your story with other men (in private, not performatively) /2
author: anamariecox

text: W/r/t sexual predators making “comebacks”: it’s another situation where 12-steps offer a helpful template (in addition to an actual program, SLAA). Don’t apologize and assume that’s enough. It never is. Ask (an expert, if not your victims) what you can do to *make things right.*
